IntroductionSection.Title: Together, the osteosarcoma community has the power to move research forward
IntroductionSection.Text: By generating the most comprehensive osteosarcoma database, we can accelerate research and the development of new therapies. Only you hold the key to unlock future discoveries.

Step1.Text: Share your experiences, access to medical records, and samples.

Step2.Text: The anonymous study data is shared widely with the biomedical community so all may learn together.

Step3.Text: This will accelerate the ability of researchers to make discoveries.

Diagnosed.Title: If you or your child have ever been diagnosed with osteosarcoma
Diagnosed.Text: You can make an impact by telling us about your or your child’s cancer. Share experiences, access to medical records, a saliva sample, and if you choose, tissue and blood samples to drive new discoveries. Depending on the age at enrollment, patients may enroll themselves. Younger patients will need the help of their parents.

PassedAway.Title: If your child has passed away from osteosarcoma
PassedAway.Text: You can make an impact by answering questions about your child’s diagnosis and experiences to advance our understanding of osteosarcoma.

AllowList.Title: You can choose to allow the study team to:
AllowList.Option1: send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample
AllowList.Option2: request copies of your medical records

Opt-inToList.Title: You may also opt-in to:
Opt-inToList.Option2: allowing the team to request a portion of tumor tissue (if available)

ClosingText.Part2: — with your permission, we’ll obtain copies of your medical records and send you a saliva kit.

ImagesAlts.ZSOFAlt: The Zach Sobiech Osteosarcoma Fund logo

MailingListSection.Title: Want to stay informed on the OS Project?
MailingListSection.Text: We'll keep you up-to-date on developments, you can unsubscribe at any time.

ClosingSection.Title: Please join us in saying “Count Me In!”
ClosingSection.Text: With your help, the osteosarcoma community can be the driving force behind transformative research.

Text.Main: The Osteosarcoma Project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.

CMISection.Paragraph1: is stewarded by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Emerson Collective.
CMISection.Paragraph2: The Osteosarcoma Project has been designed and implemented collaboratively with osteosarcoma patients, advocates, caregivers, loved ones, cancer researchers, and clinicians.

PACSection.Title: Project Advisory Council
PACSection.Text: The Osteosarcoma Project Advisory Council (PAC) is made up of patients, advocates, caregivers, and loved ones who have been impacted by osteosarcoma. The PAC meets regularly with the project operations team via video calls to develop all aspects of the project, including survey questions, the project website, the project name and logo, and sample kits.

LearnMoreSection.Text: Learn more about participating in the Osteosarcoma Project

IntroText.Paragraph1: The Osteosarcoma Project (OSP) takes a new approach to cancer research in which patients contribute their experiences, clinical information, and samples to make data freely available for any osteosarcoma researchers. By generating the most comprehensive database for osteosarcoma, the entire cancer research community can make discoveries that can lead to a better understanding of the disease and changes for future treatments. The project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research. The project also works in collaboration with a growing coalition of nonprofit advocacy partners.

Paragraph2.Part1: This project has been built with the guidance and input of many different members of the osteosarcoma community. Below we have answered some general questions about this project, as well as questions that are specific to different members of the community - please read any and all that may apply. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to us at

Items.Question: What is the goal of the Osteosarcoma Project?
Paragraphs: The goal of this project is to generate a large dataset that includes genomic, clinical, molecular, and patient reported information that can be shared with the biomedical community in order to accelerate discoveries and better therapies for this disease. Cancer is not a single disease, and each medical record, tumor, and patient's story holds part of the puzzle. Our goal is to help the research community understand the landscape of osteosarcoma and accelerate discoveries by making data more readily available.

Items.Question: Who is conducting this research?
Paragraphs: This project is being conducted by Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients & researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research. Count Me In is stewarded by four leading organizations: The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital. The Osteo Project also works in collaboration with a growing coalition of nonprofit advocacy partners. Our team is made up of cancer researchers, physicians, clinical specialists, and patient advocates. Learn more about us here.

Items.Question: How has the osteosarcoma community been involved in the design of this project?
Paragraphs: We have worked closely with patients, parents, and patient advocates within the osteosarcoma community from the beginning of this project through its design and implementation. The community has been involved in all aspects including concept, goals, messaging, forms, and the design of this website. We have also worked with a Scientific Advisory Council made up of leading researchers working in osteosarcoma.
We're proud to have as our Advocacy Partners MIB Agents to partner with and support this project.

Items.Question: Are there any costs for me to participate?
Paragraphs: No, there are no costs to you.

Items.Question: Is this research being conducted for profit?
Paragraphs: No. This project is a not-for-profit research endeavor. Our mission is to generate, aggregate, and freely share data that has had readily identifiable information removed with the research community in order to accelerate discoveries.

Items.Question: Is this study a clinical trial?
Paragraphs: This study is not a clinical trial. Participation will not have any impact on you/your child’s course of care for osteosarcoma. We are not permitted to give any clinical advice as part of your/your child’s participation in this project. We are also not able to return any individual results to people participating in this project as all testing is research-grade and not clinical-grade. Please see below for further details.

Items.Question: How this is different than clinical/commercial genomic testing?
Paragraphs: There are many types of genetic sequencing. Clinical-grade genetic sequencing is done in a lab (called a CLIA lab) with strict parameters to make sure that the data is safe to use for clinical care. Our genetic sequencing is research-grade, meaning that it cannot be used to inform clinical care.

There are also different types of genetic sequencing depending on what a researcher or physician is interested in. A panel test might be looking at just one or several genes that are already known to have an impact on humans if mutated. This project performs Whole Exome Sequencing (WES), meaning that we look at all of the parts of the DNA that are being used by the body to make proteins. Finally, whole genome sequencing (WGS) is used to sequence all of the DNA in your body’s cells.
If you are interested in clinical/commercial testing, please consult your/your child’s medical team.

Items.Question: What's in a tumor and what is germline testing?
Paragraphs: Tumors are made of cells in your body whose DNA has mutated so they are no longer healthy and normally-functioning. Your/your child’s germline (also called "normal") DNA is the DNA that is in all the healthy cells in the body. We can compare your/your child’s tumor’s DNA to the normal DNA to learn more about the genetic mutations that are present in your/your child’s cancer. Germline testing looks at the normal DNA in your/your child’s body. This is sometimes done to see if there is a mutation present that may have been inherited.

FaqSections.Title: I/my child have been diagnosed with osteosarcoma

Items.Question: How does this project work?
Paragraphs: A. Tell us about yourself or your child.

Click "Count Me In" and complete a simple online form to tell us about yourself/your child. Our goal is to perform genomics studies that will enable us to understand the genomic underpinnings of this disease. In order to understand this disease, we need to hear about your/your child’s experiences with osteosarcoma and couple that information with what we learn from the DNA in your/their tumor.
B. Give us permission to collect your/your child’s samples and data.

If you are in the United States or Canada after you fill out the initial survey, we will ask you to complete an online consent form that requests your permission to obtain copies of your/your child’s medical records and a saliva sample. You may also opt-in to providing a blood sample and/or allowing us to request a small portion of your/your child’s stored tumor sample. We’ll also ask you to tell us where you/your child received medical care so we can contact the appropriate doctors and hospitals.
C. We'll find and request your/your child's records.

Our team will contact your/your child's doctors and hospitals to obtain copies of medical records. We will only request medical records from the institutions you list while registering. This is a manual process and takes time. Medical records typically are either faxed or mailed to us upon our requests—none come in automatically as a result of participation in this project, regardless of your/your child's physician’s knowledge of participation in this project.

If you have opted in to sharing tumor tissue, our team may also request a small portion of your/your child’s stored tumor samples. We will ask pathology departments to share only a part of the tumor tissue, and not to share anything with us that might be needed for clinical care.
D. Send Us a Saliva Kit.
We'll also send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample from you/your child, which will contain "healthy" germline DNA that can be compared with DNA from your/your child’s tumor sample.
E. We'll Analyze Your/Your Child’s Tumor and Medical Data.

We will perform cutting-edge, comprehensive genomic analyses on your/your child's saliva, tumor, and/or blood sample. Sequencing data we generate will be securely stored in a protected database at the Broad Institute along with information from your/your child’s medical record. Any information that would make it easy to identify you/your child as an individual will be removed from all genomic and clinical data.
F. We'll Share the Data with Other Researchers.

Once potentially identifying information has been removed, our database of genomic and medical information (with your/your child’s identifying information removed) will be shared with the National Institutes of Health and the cancer research community, and will be able to be used for other genomic and molecular studies to help understand osteosarcoma and develop new therapies. To see what kind of data we will be generating you can reference our sister project's, the Metastatic Breast Cancer Project, data on mbcproject.org/data-release. By sharing all sequencing and clinical data with multiple public databases, we will enable anyone to use this data to accelerate research.

Items.Question: What happens when my child with osteosarcoma becomes an adult?
Paragraphs: When your child reaches the age of consenting for themselves, they need to consent themselves to continue to participate in the project. For the US and Canada, this varies by locations and is between ages 18 and 21.

If your child remains in the study when they reach the age of consenting for themselves, the project team will contact them to re-consent to the study. We will contact you to get your child’s contact information. If your child consents, the project team will continue to request medical records and tissue samples from any point in your child’s osteosarcoma treatment.

FaqSections.Title: My child passed away from osteosarcoma

Items.Question: Can I participate if my child has passed away from osteosarcoma?
Paragraphs: Yes. You can click "Count Me In", and there will be an option to indicate that your child has passed away. This will lead to a survey that will ask questions about your child’s experience with osteosarcoma. Your responses will give researchers unique insights into this cancer and has the power to inform future directions for studies in this rare cancer.

We will provide regular updates as the study progresses about the status of the project and information about new studies that we are conducting. We will also share any discoveries from these research projects with you.

Items.Question: Can I provide access to medical records and tissue on behalf of someone who passed away?
Paragraphs: The Osteosarcoma Project cannot currently obtain medical records or tissue samples for individuals who have passed away. We are exploring future plans for next-of-kin process, but this will take time to develop. Through the Loved Ones survey, you may choose to opt-in to be re-contacted by the study if a process is developed to enable this.

FaqSections.Title: I am a member of the community who would like to get involved

Items.Question: How can I spread the word about the Osteosarcoma Project?
Paragraphs: If you would like to learn more about how to spread the word about the project, or if you have any suggestions or questions about the project, please email us at info@osproject.org.

Items.Question: How can I receive updates on the Osteosarcoma Project?
Paragraphs: If you would like updates on the project, please sign up for our mailing list.

ErrorPage.Title: We've encountered an error
ErrorPage.Text: We're sorry, but an error has occurred.

DefaultText.TextPt1: Please wait a moment and retry. If the trouble persists, please email us at

ErrorCodes.PASSWORD_RESET_LINK_EXPIRED: Your password reset link has expired.

StayInformed.Title: Stay informed
StayInformed.Text: Thank you for joining the email list. We'll send you updates and keep you informed. You can unsubscribe at any time. If you have any questions about your status in the project, please email

LovedOneThankYou.Title: Thank you!
LovedOneThankYou.ThankYou: Thank you for taking the time to take the survey and share your Loved One’s experience with osteosarcoma.
LovedOneThankYou.StayInTouch: We’ll stay in touch with you so that you can see the progress that we are making towards advancements in the understanding of osteosarcoma.

Contacts.TextPt1: We'd also like to hear from you if you have any additional thoughts you'd like to share — please feel free to email us at

LovedOneThankYou.ThankYouAgain: Thank you again for sharing with us and supporting the entire osteosarcoma community. If you’d like to help us reach patients or other community members, feel free to share the project. Together, we can move research forward for the osteosarcoma community.

AgeUpThankYou.Title: Thank you!
AgeUpThankYou.EmailVerified: Your email address has been verified. We will be sending an email with more information on re-consent shortly after your birthday.

EmailCollected.TextPt1: An email will be sent to your child to confirm their address and tell them about the upcoming re-consent process. If you need to change the email you provided for your child, please contact the project team at

You can unsubscribe at any time.
